speaker: DYER
line: You’re supposed to be in charge here, Perkins.

speaker: PERKINS
line: I am in charge.

speaker: DYER
line: Well, these men want some answers. They want to know what you’re plan is. Let’s face it, this thing could kill us all.

speaker: PERKINS
line: We should’ve been gone two days ago. Nobody would listen to me.

speaker: DYER
line: Nobody knew what it was two days ago, Perkins. Nobody knows now.

speaker: PERKINS
line: Somebody has to go for help.

speaker: DYER
line: What about the rest of us? What are we supposed to do? Just wait here until help arrives?

speaker: PERKINS
line: We have to take a chance, one of us has to hike out!

speaker: DYER
line: That person might not make it in time. He might not make it down to the road before nightfall! Then what? I say we make a run for it, split up, take our chances!

speaker: PERKINS
line: It’s suicide, Dyer.

speaker: DYER
line: Fine. You stay here. Tell us how it turns out.

speaker: MAN
line: Hurry up!

speaker: ANOTHER MAN
line: You’re going the wrong way!

speaker: DYER
line: I think it’s broken.

speaker: PERKINS
line: Come on, you got to get up.

speaker: DYER
line: I don’t think I can make it.

speaker: PERKINS
line: We gotta keep moving.

speaker: DYER
line: We’re not going to make it. We’re not going...

speaker: MULDER
line: Take a good look, Scully.

speaker: SCULLY
line: What am I looking at?

speaker: MULDER
line: Thirty loggers working a clear-cutting contract in Washington State. Rugged, manly men in the full bloom of their manhood.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Right, but what am I looking for?

speaker: MULDER
line: Anything strange, unexplainable, unlikely... boyfriend?

speaker: SCULLY
line: I don’t know, I... I give up, Mulder.

speaker: MULDER
line: You give up? Funny, that’s apparently what the Federal Forest Service has done as well.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Why, what happened to them?

speaker: MULDER
line: In a word, they vanished. Or so it would appear. This is Doug Spinney and Steven Teague. They call themselves "monkey wrenchers." The guys who drive spikes into trees, sabotage logging equipment and otherwise make life miserable for lumberjacks and lumbermills.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Ecoterrorists or militant environmentalists.

speaker: MULDER
line: Right. Two weeks ago, the group of loggers I just showed you radioed a message that Spinney and Teague had gone on a spree. Spiking trees, sabotaging equipment, causing general mischief. One week later, all radio communication was cut off.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Do they know why?

speaker: MULDER
line: No. The lumber company that employs the men has asked the Federal Forest Service to look into the matter. Two officials were sent in a week ago and no one has heard from them since.

speaker: SCULLY
line: It appears as if these monkey wrenchers are doing more than just a little mischief-making.

speaker: MULDER
line: That’s what the lumber company and the Federal Forest Service are accusing. They’ve asked the F.B.I. to investigate. I had to pull a few strings to make sure we got the case.

speaker: SCULLY
line: For an ecoterrorism case? Do I dare ask why?

speaker: MULDER
line: In 1934, long before anyone even knew what an ecoterrorist was, a W.P.A. crew vanished from that same area without a trace. Not one of those men was ever found or heard from again.

speaker: SCULLY
line: And you suspect what? Bigfoot?

speaker: MULDER
line: Not likely. That’s a lot of flannel to be choking down even for Bigfoot. Come on, Scully, it’ll be a nice trip to the forest.

speaker: MULDER
line: Hi. Fox Mulder, this is Dana Scully, we’re with the F.B.I.

speaker: MOORE
line: Larry Moore, Federal Forest Service. You can put your gear in the back of the truck.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Must be pretty rugged where we’re going, huh?

speaker: MOORE
line: Yeah.

speaker: MULDER
line: What’s that in your windshield there? Is that a bullet hole?

speaker: MOORE
line: .22 caliber.

speaker: MULDER
line: Somebody took a shot at you?

speaker: MOORE
line: So it would appear. There’s not much to hunt around here with that type of ammo except Freddies.

speaker: SCULLY
line: "Freddies?"

speaker: MOORE
line: Employees of the Federal Forest Service. It’s, uh, it’s what the ecoterrorists call us.

speaker: MULDER
line: Is that who you think took a shot at you?

speaker: MOORE
line: Let me get this out of the way. I have no quarrel with these ecoterrorists in principle. And I’m as concerned for this forest and the environment as anybody. It’s their methods I can’t condone.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Do you think they’d go so far as to kill a man?

speaker: MOORE
line: Well, there’s thirty men up there unaccounted for, each with survival experience. Something happened to them.

speaker: HUMPHREYS
line: Sorry I’m late. I was down talking to Bob Perkins’ wife. He’s one of our missing loggers. Hey, Larry.

speaker: MOORE
line: Hey.

speaker: HUMPHREYS
line: Steve Humphreys, head of security for Schiff-Immergut Lumber.

speaker: MULDER
line: Mulder, Scully.

speaker: HUMPHREYS
line: Well, we’ve got a four hour drive ahead of us. Plenty of time to get to know each other.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Get the impression that we’ve walked into the middle of a war that’s already started? Why do these men work so far up in the wilderness?

speaker: HUMPHREYS
line: That’s where the trees are.

speaker: SCULLY
line: You’re kidding, right?

speaker: HUMPHREYS
line: No, environmentalists have pretty much made sure that all the land you see here is untouchable. We’re forced to take our timber where we can get it. Even then, we plant saplings for every tree we take.

speaker: MULDER
line: So why do the ecoterrorists target you?

speaker: HUMPHREYS
line: See, these tree-huggers comes from the same kind of boys that went up to Canada during the Vietnam war. They’re cowardly and so are their tactics.

speaker: MOORE
line: Damn it. Homemade tire spike. Clear through the sidewall. It’s unfixable.

speaker: MULDER
line: You got a spare, don’t you?

speaker: HUMPHREYS
line: Right tire’s history too. Monkey wrenchers call it a caltrop. The roads back here are littered with them. Indiscriminate terrorism. Can you imagine somebody putting these down or spiking the roads of Washington, D.C.? I’d like to see how much sympathy they get then.

speaker: SCULLY
line: So how are we going to get up to the camp?

speaker: MOORE
line: We’re going to have to hike. Anybody here?

speaker: MULDER
line: Someone forgot to clean their plate.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Looks like they left in a hurry too.

speaker: HUMPHREYS
line: Find anything?

speaker: MULDER
line: Party favors.

speaker: HUMPHREYS
line: All the vehicles have all been monkey wrenched, power generator’s busted.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Somebody really turned this place upside-down.

speaker: HUMPHREYS
line: Whoever did it didn’t want the fact broadcast, either.

speaker: MOORE
line: Radiators are all full of rice. Looks like sugar or sand in the crankcases. They really did a number here.

speaker: HUMPHREYS
line: Sun’s going down in an hour and a half.

speaker: MOORE
line: Better take a look around before it gets dark.

speaker: HUMPHREYS
line: I’ll see if I can get that generator working.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Well, you were right about one thing.

speaker: MULDER
line: What’s that?

speaker: SCULLY
line: It definitely wasn’t Bigfoot.

speaker: MULDER
line: Look at that.

speaker: SCULLY
line: What is it?

speaker: MOORE
line: Looks like a hive. Maybe a cocoon of some kind.

speaker: MULDER
line: Made by what?

speaker: MOORE
line: I don’t know, I’ve never seen anything like it.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Got it.

speaker: MOORE
line: Can you cut it down?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Yeah, I think so.

speaker: MULDER
line: You alright, Scully?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Oh God... It feels, uh... it feels dessicated and hard and dry, almost... preserved.

speaker: MOORE
line: Like it’s been enbalmed.

speaker: SCULLY
line: No, more like all the fluids have been bled from this body. Almost like it’s been cured. I think... it’s a male.

speaker: MULDER
line: Barely.

speaker: MOORE
line: I’d say it’s, uh, some kind of spider’s nest or insect cocoon.

speaker: SCULLY
line: What kind of an insect could have gotten a man all the way up into that tree?

speaker: MULDER
line: Itsy-bitsy spider.

speaker: HUMPHREYS
line: Don’t move. Who are you? Doug Spinney. I oughta shoot you where you stand.

speaker: SPINNEY
line: Might as well shoot yourself too.

speaker: HUMPHREYS
line: You’re in a hell of a spot to be testing me. What happened to my men?

speaker: SPINNEY
line: What men?

speaker: HUMPHREYS
line: The men who were working this camp.

speaker: SPINNEY
line: I don’t know what happened to them. Probably the same thing that’ll happen to us when the sun goes down.

speaker: MULDER
line: What are you doing?

speaker: HUMPHREYS
line: This animal is Doug Spinney. He’s the man responsible for all the monkey wrenching. He’s probably a murderer as well.

speaker: SPINNEY
line: I’m no murderer.

speaker: HUMPHREYS
line: You’re a liar.

speaker: MULDER
line: Let’s just hear what he has to say.

speaker: SPINNEY
line: If we stand around here talking, there’ll be nothing left to say. I’d start thinking about how to get that generator started. Darkness is our enemy.

speaker: HUMPHREYS
line: What’s he talking about?

speaker: SPINNEY
line: Someone want to give me a hand?

speaker: HUMPHREYS
line: Now he’s giving orders? I’m the one who fixed the damn thing!

speaker: MULDER
line: Hey, it’s alright. Why did you say that darkness was our enemy?

speaker: SPINNEY
line: That’s when they come.

speaker: SCULLY
line: When who comes?

speaker: SPINNEY
line: I don’t know what it is. They come from the sky, take a man right off his feet and devour him alive. I saw it happen.

speaker: MULDER
line: Happen to who?

speaker: SPINNEY
line: I need to eat. I haven’t eaten in three days.

speaker: HUMPHREYS
line: What kind of a B.S. story is that, huh? You believe that?

speaker: SCULLY
line: We found something in the forest.

speaker: HUMPHREYS
line: What?

speaker: MOORE
line: A man caught in some kind of insect cocoon.

speaker: MULDER
line: What happened here?

speaker: SPINNEY
line: We camped two valleys over, four of us. Three now.

speaker: HUMPHREYS
line: More rats for the wood pile.

speaker: SPINNEY
line: Our truck has a dead battery so we drew straws to see who would make the hike over here to steal one from the loggers.

speaker: MULDER
line: Why not just hike out?

speaker: SPINNEY
line: More than a day’s hike. No way we’d want to be caught out in the forest after dark. Not after what happened to Teague.

speaker: SCULLY
line: That’s the man you said that was devoured alive?

speaker: SPINNEY
line: Yeah.

speaker: MULDER
line: What are you guys doing out here?

speaker: SPINNEY
line: Camping.

speaker: HUMPHREYS
line: Yeah, right. The kind of camping you do is a federal offense.

speaker: MULDER
line: Just, just hold off a second, okay?

speaker: MOORE
line: No, he’s right. This man is an admitted felon. He could be placed under arrest.

speaker: SPINNEY
line: What about your offense, my friend, huh? What about the offense against nature you perpetrate?

speaker: HUMPHREYS
line: We operate completely within the law. We pay for the right to take those trees.

speaker: SPINNEY
line: Oh, yeah? Well, I got news for you. Your logging crew has taken trees that nobody has the right to, trees that are marked and protected so don’t talk to me about breaking the law! Sir.

speaker: MOORE
line: They’ve been taking marked trees?

speaker: SPINNEY
line: Yes sir, marked in orange.

speaker: MOORE
line: Old growth trees? You know anything about that, Steve?

speaker: HUMPHREYS
line: No. You going to take this man’s word over mine?

speaker: SPINNEY
line: You don’t want to go out in the night. Take my word on that. It’s out there.

speaker: HUMPHREYS
line: What? If I go out that door, something’s going to attack me, eat me alive and spin me in it’s web?

speaker: SPINNEY
line: Yes.

speaker: HUMPHREYS
line: What, it’s too polite to come in here and get me?

speaker: SPINNEY
line: For some reason, it’s, uh, afraid of the light.

speaker: HUMPHREYS
line: It’s afraid of the light.

speaker: MOORE
line: There may be something to what he’s saying, Steve.

speaker: HUMPHREYS
line: You know what I think? I think this man is a liar and a murderer and just clever enough to make up a story like that. Even whip up that cocoon just to save a few trees and I’m going to prove I’m right. This is ridiculous. Where is it, Spinney? I thought it was going to come and, uh, devour me! Hey! Here I am! Come out, come out wherever you! Aw, don’t be shy! Come on! Huh? It’s just like a told ya. There’s nothing out here but a bunch of trees. Trees that this man values more than human life. And I’m going to see him tried on murder charges.

speaker: SCULLY
line: What do you think?

speaker: MULDER
line: I think I’m going to suggest that we sleep with the lights on.

speaker: SPINNEY
line: You see this Douglas Fir? It’s been standing here since before your time and your men cut it down.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Who marks these trees?

speaker: MOORE
line: Federal Forest Service. They’re only supposed to cut trees with a blue "X."

speaker: MULDER
line: This tree must be hundreds of years old.

speaker: MOORE
line: At least.

speaker: SCULLY
line: You must get a lot of lumber from a big tree like this.

speaker: SPINNEY
line: Thousands of boards. Hell of a lot easier than taking a lot of smaller, younger trees.

speaker: HUMPHREYS
line: Well, let me remind you that monkey wrenchers like Spinney here are not above marking trees with their own paint.

speaker: MOORE
line: This tree’s 500 years old if it’s a day, Steve.

speaker: MULDER
line: Hey, look at this. What would this represent?

speaker: MOORE
line: I don’t know. I’ve never seen a ring like that before.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Those center rings are the older rings, right?

speaker: MOORE
line: Yeah. Every ring represents a season growth. And you see these? These are 500, 600 years old. They’re a recorded history of rainfall and climate. But this one... I don’t know. I should take a core sample.

speaker: HUMPHREYS
line: Have we finished with this nature walk? I want an answer to what happened to those loggers.

speaker: SCULLY
line: That’s what we’re trying to determine, sir.

speaker: HUMPHREYS
line: Looking at a tree stump? Don’t you think you should be interrogating this man?

speaker: MULDER
line: I don’t think he did it.

speaker: HUMPHREYS
line: Well, I think he did and I want him arrested.

speaker: MULDER
line: Well, he’s not going anywhere!

speaker: HUMPHREYS
line: No, not with a gun on him. But what happens when you’re poking around and his three buddies show up and do to you what they probably did to those two Federal Forest officers? Huh? Larry?

speaker: MOORE
line: I just want to take a core sample of this tree, Steve.

speaker: HUMPHREYS
line: Hey, I got families down there who want some answers about their loved ones and so do you! Answers that aren’t going to be found in that tree.

speaker: SPINNEY
line: Only crime we’re here to investigate is the death of that tree.

speaker: HUMPHREYS
line: Yeah, we’ll see about that.

speaker: MOORE
line: Steve, where you going?

speaker: HUMPHREYS
line: I’m going to hike down to your truck, get on the horn and get some people up here who’ll take some action!

speaker: MOORE
line: Steve!

speaker: SPINNEY
line: Aw, let him go. Let him find out for himself.

speaker: MOORE
line: This is odd. This yellow ring’s got something living in it, some kind of… tiny bug. It doesn’t make sense.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Why not?

speaker: MOORE
line: Well, parasites attack a tree in a variety of ways, but they always attack the living parts. The leaves, the roots, the new growth rings. Even if they’re borers of something, they wouldn’t be working so deep in the tree.

speaker: MULDER
line: Maybe the wood in this ring is different. They’re feeding on it.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Can you identify them?

speaker: MOORE
line: It’s a wood mite of some kind. It’s nothing I’ve ever seen before.

speaker: MULDER
line: Could they have been living in that tree for hundreds of years?

speaker: MOORE
line: I don’t see how. I mean, these inner rings are essentially dead wood. The tree’s vascular system is limited to the outer few rings, they need water to survive.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Well, they appear to be hatching out of the porous wood. Maybe when you drew out this core, you tapped into a larger nest.

speaker: SPINNEY
line: Can they build a cocoon? Right after that tree was cut down is when Teague died. It’s about the same time the loggers disappeared too.

speaker: SCULLY
line: You think these mites are what killed the men?

speaker: SPINNEY
line: Maybe they been lying there dormant for hundreds of years. Maybe they woke up hungry.

speaker: HUMPHREYS
line: Damn it! Alright, you monkey wrenchers! Come on out now! I know what you’re up to!

speaker: MOORE
line: Humphreys should have been back by now.

speaker: SCULLY
line: These bugs aren’t moving anymore. They’re either dead or they’re asleep.

speaker: SPINNEY
line: It’s the light. They don’t like the light.

speaker: SCULLY
line: That’s weird, I mean, usually bugs are attracted to light.

speaker: SPINNEY
line: These obviously are not your ordinary bugs to say the least.

speaker: MULDER
line: What do you know about insects, Scully?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Uh, just what I learned in my biology courses. That they’re the foundation of our ecosystem. That there’s lots of them, something like 200 million per person on this planet.

speaker: MULDER
line: And they’ve been around a long time, right?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Yeah, something like 600 million years, even before the dinosaurs. Why?

speaker: MULDER
line: And this tree is what, 5, 6, 700 years old?

speaker: MOORE
line: Yeah.

speaker: MULDER
line: And these rings represent a history of climatic changes, which means that in this year or season in the life of the tree, there was some kind of strange event that produced an abnormal ring.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Well, like what, exactly?

speaker: MULDER
line: A volcanic eruption. This whole chain of mountains running from Washington to Oregon is still extremely active. Remember Mt. St. Helens?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Yeah, but how does that explain the bugs?

speaker: MULDER
line: When Mt. St. Helens erupted, there was a large amount of radiation that was released from inside the earth. Strange things started to grow. There’s actually this lake where they’ve discovered a kind of amoeba that can literally suck a man’s brains out.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Oh, a brain-sucking amoeba.

speaker: SPINNEY
line: No, it’s true. Spirit Lake. And there’s documented cases of swimmers being infected.

speaker: SCULLY
line: But an amoeba is a single-celled organism. It can be mutated. An insect is a complex animal. It would take years and years to evolve.

speaker: MULDER
line: Well, then maybe what we’re dealing with isn’t a mutation at all. What if it’s some kind of... extinct insect larvae in that ring, deposited during a period of volcanic activity, brought up through the tree’s root system. Ancient insect eggs. Thousands, maybe millions of years old lying dormant until...

speaker: SPINNEY
line: Until those loggers cut down that tree. That would be rather poetic justice, don’t you think? Unleashing the very thing that would end up killing them and your friend Humphreys? And who knows? Maybe us. Sweet dreams.

speaker: MOORE
line: Humphreys might have just hiked out of here. We don’t know that he didn’t. Maybe we’re letting ourselves get carried away with this bug story.

speaker: MULDER
line: Yeah, maybe. Going somewhere?

speaker: SPINNEY
line: No, I was just...

speaker: MULDER
line: Doing a little auto repair. Looks to me like you’re planning on cutting out of here.

speaker: SPINNEY
line: I gotta save my friends. They only had enough gas to keep their generator running fifteen, twenty hours max. They’re gonna die if I don’t get back there.

speaker: MULDER
line: So why are you sneaking around?

speaker: SPINNEY
line: Freddy. Forest Service guy, he wouldn’t go for it. He’d never trust me.

speaker: MULDER
line: He’s got no reason to. Neither do I.

speaker: SPINNEY
line: Look, I can save us all, man. We’ve got a jeep over there, it’s just two valleys over, all it needs is a battery. Now, I can get there, I can get back here in the morning. We can all drive out tomorrow. You got to trust me, man.

speaker: MULDER
line: Radio is back up.

speaker: SCULLY
line: It’s working?

speaker: MULDER
line: I’m not getting any reception so the reciever could be trashed.

speaker: SCULLY
line: What about transmissions, could we send a message?

speaker: MULDER
line: We could try. This is a call for help, is there anyone at this frequency? This is Special Agent Mulder of the F.B.I., we have an emergency and a possible quarantine situation. Our position is... What happened to the generator?

speaker: MOORE
line: I turned it off.

speaker: MULDER
line: Well, turn it back on, I got the radio working.

speaker: MOORE
line: What happened to the gas can?

speaker: MULDER
line: Spinney took it.

speaker: MOORE
line: He took it? You mean he’s gone?

speaker: MULDER
line: He left earlier this morning. He took a battery and some gas. He’s gonna come back for us in the morning.

speaker: MOORE
line: Yeah, what, he gave you his personal guarantee on that?

speaker: MULDER
line: He gave me his word, yeah.

speaker: MOORE
line: Did you stop to think that the man who gave you his word has made an art out of sabotage? And defying authority? And is probably the same man who put the bullet through my windshield?

speaker: MULDER
line: Well, what would you have done? At least now we’ve got one chance of getting out of here alive which is one more chance than we had before.

speaker: MOORE
line: Or one less.

speaker: SCULLY
line: What do you mean?

speaker: MOORE
line: Your partner let Spinney leave with the last of the gas. This generator’s got about a quarter tank left, maybe less.

speaker: SCULLY
line: What about the gas in the trucks?

speaker: MULDER
line: There is no more gas, the other tanks have all been ruptured or filled with sugar.

speaker: MOORE
line: By the same man who we are now trusting to keep his word and come back for us.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Well, then we’ve got to get back on the radio, we’ve got to send out a mayday.

speaker: MOORE
line: Every drop of fuel we waste is fuel that’s gonna keep this gennie powered tonight. I mean, I don’t want to be waiting around hoping somebody heard that transmission when this thing quits running about two o’clock in the morning. Do you?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder...

speaker: MULDER
line: Look, it’s done. I shouldn’t have let him go. Let’s just move past it, okay?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Fine. What do you suggest?

speaker: MULDER
line: I don’t know. We’ll think of something.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Look, I think we both have a pretty good idea of what happened to those loggers and what happened to the group in 1934.

speaker: MULDER
line: We only found one cocoon.

speaker: SCULLY
line: It’s a big forest.

speaker: MULDER
line: Look, Scully, what would you have done?

speaker: SCULLY
line: You mean, would I have made a decision by myself that would have affected the whole group?

speaker: MULDER
line: Oh, will you cut the sanctimonious crap?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Well, what do you want me to say? Let’s face it, Mulder, we might die up here! If we’re lucky, they’ll find our bodies spun up in a tree or they may not find us at all!

speaker: MULDER
line: You’re right. And we’re wasting time arguing about it.

speaker: SCULLY
line: What are you going to do?

speaker: MULDER
line: Button this place up. If we’re gonna spend the night in here, we’ve got to do everything we can to make sure the bugs stay out there.

speaker: MOORE
line: I’d be careful with that. It’s the only bulb that works.

speaker: SCULLY
line: I can see them. You guys, look at this. Look, they’re coming through the wall down where it’s dark. You see them? They’re on me.

speaker: MULDER
line: It’s alright, Scully, Scully...

speaker: SCULLY
line: Get them off me!

speaker: MULDER
line: Stop moving! Stop!

speaker: MOORE
line: Whoa, watch it!

speaker: MULDER
line: Stand still! Stand still!

speaker: SCULLY
line: Can you see them? Mulder, get them off me!

speaker: MULDER
line: They’re not just on you. They’re everywhere. I think that’s what that greasy residue is over everything.

speaker: SCULLY
line: I thought we were supposed to be safe in the light!

speaker: MULDER
line: We are. I think the light keeps them from swarming. We’ll be safe as long as we stay in the light. How are you doing?

speaker: SCULLY
line: I’m okay. They’re oxidizing enzymes. Just like fireflies. Maybe that’s why they cocoon their prey... so they can oxidize the proteins taken from the fluids in the body. What if the generator goes? Are they all going to swarm in here and drain the life out of us?

speaker: MULDER
line: We got an hour and a half till sunrise.

speaker: SCULLY
line: And then what? It’s over a day’s hike out of here. We won’t make it on foot by nightfall.

speaker: MULDER
line: Maybe somebody heard our radio transmission. Help could be on the way.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Oh, you sent that call hours ago. I mean, help would have been here by now.

speaker: MULDER
line: Well, I’m not going to give up on Spinney. He gave me his word he’d come back to get us.

speaker: SCULLY
line: And if he doesn’t?

speaker: MULDER
line: We’ll think of something. You got a patch kit or an extra tube in your truck?

speaker: MOORE
line: Yeah.

speaker: MULDER
line: Maybe we can patch this or at least get it to hold some air. With the spare in your truck, maybe we can limp down the mountain. If not, at least we can get on the radio and warn them what’s out there.

speaker: MOORE
line: See it?

speaker: MULDER
line: Yeah.

speaker: MOORE
line: Listen. You hear that? It’s a car!

speaker: MULDER
line: No, it’s a jeep!

speaker: SPINNEY
line: We gotta move, let’s go! Let’s go!

speaker: MOORE
line: Wait! What about the body... Humphrey’s body?

speaker: SPINNEY
line: Leave it, I’ve radioed for help.

speaker: MULDER
line: What happened to your friends?

speaker: SPINNEY
line: They didn’t make it. We’re not going to make it either unless we haul ass! Damn it! I don’t believe it.

speaker: MOORE
line: When you talk about shooting yourself in the foot...

speaker: MULDER
line: Get out of there! Get back in the car!

speaker: MAN
line: We have an emergency evacuation situation. Requesting quarantine facility for two, possibly three victims with undiagnosed infection or exposure to unknown biological vectors. Repeat, that’s an emergency evacuation situation. Two, possibly three victims...

speaker: ANNOUNCER
line: Attention, all personnel. High level bio-clearance required on third floor.

speaker: MAN
line: How are you feeling?

speaker: MULDER
line: Better. How did the tests come back?

speaker: MAN
line: Your respiratory charts were good. We’re more concerned with the extent of damage due to inhalation. There were large concentrations of the chemical determined as Luciferene.

speaker: MULDER
line: Which is what?

speaker: MAN
line: The same enzymes we find in fireflies and other bioluminescent insects. Our entomologists are still trying to determine the specific epithet of the insects you encountered.

speaker: MULDER
line: Scully? How is she doing?

speaker: MAN
line: She’s still not out of the woods, so to speak. She lost a lot of fluids. Two or three more hours of exposure, she might not have made it.

speaker: MULDER
line: I told her it was going to be a nice trip to the forest. How you going to contain it to the forest. What if the swarm migrates?

speaker: MAN
line: The government has initiated eradication procedures. They’re quite certain that by using a combination of controlled burns and pesticides, they will be successful.

speaker: MULDER
line: And if they’re not?

speaker: MAN
line: That is not an option, Mr. Mulder.
